_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of Land View, Inc. (LVI) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations in Minidoka, ID.  At this Facility, LVI engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of chemicals (i.e. retail) to customers, most of who use LVI's products to support agricultural operations (See Section 3.0 of the PSM/RMPr).  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Minidoka Facility located approximately 0.5 miles west-southwest of Minidoka at 925 N. Highway 24, Rupert, ID 83350.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Minidoka Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Minidoka Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



LVI recently completed a compliance audit of its Minidoka Facility.  As a result of this compliance audit, LVI determined that it operated five (5) covered processes instead of a one (1) covered process.  All relevant sections for a Program 3 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility PSM/RMPr.



FACILITY



The Minidoka Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates five covered processes that include (1) Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage; (2) Covered Process 2: 10-34-0 Reacting; (3) Covered Process 3: Storage and Handling (Anhydrous Ammonia); (4) Cover

ed Process 4: Aqua Ammonia Reacting; and (5) Covered Process 5: Storage and Handling (Aqua Ammonia).  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via 34,000-gallon railcars (Covered Process 1) or a 9,000-gallon commercial tanker truck.  As related to Covered Process 2, the anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the railcars and to a mobile pipe reactor to manufacture 10-34-0 Fertilizer.  As related to Covered Process 3, the anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the railcars to two 18,000-gallon stationary storage tanks and from the storage tanks to nurse tanks or to the aqua ammonia reactor.  As related to Covered Process 4, anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the 18,000-gallon storage tanks or railcar to manufacture aqua ammonia and from the aqua reactor to two 32,000-gallon stationary storage tanks.  As related to Covered Process 5, aqua ammonia is transferred from the aqua ammonia reactor or from commercial tanker trucks into the storage tanks, or from the storage tanks to commercial tanker trucks for transportation and delivery to the client.



The Minidoka Facility owns and operates Covered Processes 3, 4, and 5 in accordance with this PSM/RMPr.  As related to Covered Process 1, Minidoka does not own or operate the railcars but does conduct inspections in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  As related to Covered Process 2, Minidoka Contracts an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC) to manufacture the 10-34-0 Fertilizer.  Minidoka requires that the IFRC have in place and operates its mobile pipe reactor equipment in accordance with an OSHA PSM.    



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for both covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single storage tank were released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as

a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes a rupture of a 2-inch line caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer line during a major loading or unloading operation.  Although this event is classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices, check valves) and operating procedures that LVI uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



Both the worst case and alternative scenario are overly conservative because even a 2-minute release is unlikely to occur since excess flow valves on the system should close immediately upon increased flow resulting from the ruptured transfer line.



LVI calculated the effected population within the modeled distance to the toxic endpoint for both the worst case and alternative case release scenarios for each covered process.  LVI used the Census Bureau LandView6 software package containing the 2000 Census tract Data to determine the effected population.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Magic Valley Manager implements the PSM/RMPr at this Facility.  The Magic Valley Manager is assisted by other LVI staff, as directed.  The Magic Valley Manager is responsible for ensuring that LVI Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



LVI's Minidoka Facility is a non-responding facility. LVI has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significan

t property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Minidoka Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by LVI at the Minidoka Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMPr will be updated as the Minidoka Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Minidoka County LEPC.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Minidoka Facility.
